snippet.textDisplay: Believe me you do NOT want to be on the receiving end of those illnesses that vaccines stop! My husband wasn’t vaccinated as a kid and he missed so much school catching the most deadliest illnesses you can think of ,measles, mumps etc he also is almost deaf in one ear from measles and said he never felt so ill in his life when he caught it. He said his room had to be dark when any light killed his eyes, he was red hot burning up 🥵 and said that he had it for weeks , it’s lucky he didn’t end up infertile or worse! And said it was even in his mouth , he couldn’t eat and was literally in bed the whole time! It’s not just a rash people. He had to have all these immunisations later on when we had kids due to the risk he posed to our pre vaccine baby. It’s just not worth your child’s life OR other children’s lives when they end up catching it from your child 😡 luckily he never got meningitis or polio!

snippet.textDisplay: How many generations have had Vaccines? snippet.textDisplay:
The reason people believe that vaccines cause Autism, is due to Wakefield and the media. Wakefield reported 12 children's clinical correlations between MMR vaccine and Autism. He found traces of the measles virus in the gut of 12 autistic children. The media repeatedly reported Wakefield's concerns. A corelational isn't proof of something existing, just leads to more research. As of 2002 the MMR vaccine was used in 90 countries and is regarded as 'safe' by medical professionals. If anyone thinks correlation is proof you should watch the Ice cream and drowning TedTalk. Research - Theguardian.co.uk - The MMR media storm
www.nhs.uk/conditions/vaccinations/mmr-vaccine/
www.gov.uk/government/publications/measles-dont-let-your-child-catch-it

snippet.textDisplay: I watched an Alex Jones vid once because I found him amusing if unhinged, and eventually my YT recommended videos got progressively more extreme, and none of the things I wanted to watch ever showed up no matter how many music and history vids I watched. My core values never changed, and my cognitive dissonance got worse and worse, until I had to go through several years of YT history to delete the offending alt right videos. My YT experience is a lot more pleasant now.

snippet.textDisplay:
Some people are attracted to conspiracy theories because it makes them feel self-important - they think they know something contrary to what most other people take for granted as true. Also, if you believe in one conspiracy, you're more likely to believe in others. This should set off alarm bells, as a claim that vaccinations are bad is an entirely different claim that the moon landings are a hoax, or the world is controlled by lizard people!


Should one be skeptical of 'big-pharma', yes. Drug companies don't have a great track record in publishing all their data and their business practices have at times been less than ethical. Do vaccines cause autism? No they don't!
Skepticism of 'big-pharma' doesn't mean that vaccines don't work!
There are plenty of studies and reviews from the pharmaceutical, university, government and private research institutions plus decades of use in the real world, that categorically conclude that for the typical person, vaccines are safe. In fact, not vaccinating is neglect and increases the risk to both yours and everyone else's children of catching a preventable illness.


Part of the reason some parents look for a reason to not vaccinate, is because they don't want to be responsible for actively harming their children - as they see it. They fail to see that vaccine hesitancy, is much more likely to harm their children and others.
snippet.textOriginal:
Some people are attracted to conspiracy theories because it makes them feel self-important - they think they know something contrary to what most other people take for granted as true. Also, if you believe in one conspiracy, you're more likely to believe in others. This should set off alarm bells, as a claim that vaccinations are bad is an entirely different claim that the moon landings are a hoax, or the world is controlled by lizard people!


Should one be skeptical of 'big-pharma', yes. Drug companies don't have a great track record in publishing all their data and their business practices have at times been less than ethical. Do vaccines cause autism? No they don't! 
Skepticism of 'big-pharma' doesn't mean that vaccines don't work! 
There are plenty of studies and reviews from the pharmaceutical, university, government and private research institutions plus decades of use in the real world, that categorically conclude that for the typical person, vaccines are safe. In fact, not vaccinating is neglect and increases the risk to both yours and everyone else's children of catching a preventable illness.


Part of the reason some parents look for a reason to not vaccinate, is because they don't want to be responsible for actively harming their children - as they see it. They fail to see that vaccine hesitancy, is much more likely to harm their children and others.

snippet.textDisplay: These attacks are based on the theory of “herd immunity.” This hypothesis was plucked out of an old college textbook. It states that the more people are immune to an infectious agent, the less likely an immune-compromised individual is to come in contact with it. In other words herd immunity serves as a human shield – a type of immunity – for “at-risk” individuals. But remember, it’s only a hypothesis.
snippet.textOriginal: These attacks are based on the theory of “herd immunity.” This hypothesis was plucked out of an old college textbook. The thing with MMR is that’s a lot to give in a single shot! Naturally no one would get all three together. So I think it’s healthier to give them it separately.
Plus I’ve worked with families with children who have autism. The children made developmental progress autistic children don’t and then regressed after MMR.
So my humble opinion is more research is needed! Including who funded the 1 million children MMR study?
Sample size alone isn’t sufficient to prove the study, there are lots of variables that needs to be looked at!

snippet.textDisplay:
He's missing one important detail: herd immunity. MMR is 95% effective - or 1 in 20 it fails on. There's also a small percentage that can't get it but they're less than the 1 in 20 so let's focus on the 5%. When 99% of all children are vaccinated and you just have the 5% who aren't, in your average classroom you have 1-2 students who might be at risk of measles. So on the off chance that one susceptible student actually gets infected, you have a 50/50 chance that a second student gets infected and that's the end of the infection. Hooray. If 20% of the class isn't vaccinated, in a class of 30, you have 6 students intentionally not vaccinated and 1 student whose vaccination failed. First off, the chance that one of those 7 students got infected is that much higher. Second, when that student gets infected, they infect 6 others in their class. Who go home and infect their siblings who go to school and infect 6 of their classmates and on and on and suddenly we have an epidemic.


You aren't just killing your kid, you're enabling the deaths of your kids' friends. You fucking monster.
snippet.textOriginal:
He's missing one important detail: herd immunity.  MMR is 95% effective - or 1 in 20 it fails on.  There's also a small percentage that can't get it but they're less than the 1 in 20 so let's focus on the 5%.  When 99% of all children are vaccinated and you just have the 5% who aren't, in your average classroom you have 1-2 students who might be at risk of measles.  So on the off chance that one susceptible student actually gets infected, you have a 50/50 chance that a second student gets infected and that's the end of the infection.  Hooray.  If 20% of the class isn't vaccinated, in a class of 30, you have 6 students intentionally not vaccinated and 1 student whose vaccination failed.  First off, the chance that one of those 7 students got infected is that much higher.  Second, when that student gets infected, they infect 6 others in their class.  Who go home and infect their siblings who go to school and infect 6 of their classmates and on and on and suddenly we have an epidemic.


You aren't just killing your kid, you're enabling the deaths of your kids' friends.  You fucking monster.

I am very intrigued to see my and more studies on the link of vaccines and other complications especially in light of cultures that do not vaccinate and live long healthy lives and have large families.

snippet.textDisplay: I'm NOT an anti-vaxxer, but do I trust the British Government on this topic... NO!  Why is that; The MMR.  Andrew Wakefield asked this question ... Why am I finding the manufactured (dead?) vaccine virus in the patient's gut when you only find the naturally occurring virus in the lungs; NEVER in the gut?  I assume he could identify differences between the manufactured and the naturally occurring virus via their RNA.  Didn't that spook the (war criminal) Blair Government.  Immediately, an ultimately successful campaign started to discredit Wakefield. BUT, has the Government, the NHS or "Big Pharma" answered Wakefield's question? ... No.  Tell me Mr Blair, when you had your children inoculated for measles, mumps & rubella, did they receive the MMR vaccine?  No answer to that one either.  I believe that (without any evidence) Blair's children were inoculated over a period of time with SEPARATE vaccines; giving the child time to recover between each cycle.  Howard: you're the fool for believing everything that "The Establishment" tells you.
